questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the difference between Cost-Benefit Analysis and Cost-Effective Analysis in health management?

options.label: A
options.text: Cost-Benefit Analysis focuses on the qualitative aspects of health services, while Cost-Effective Analysis focuses on quantitative aspects.

options.label: B
options.text: Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effectiveness Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.

options.label: C
options.text: Cost-Benefit Analysis is used for planning and budgeting, while Cost-Effective Analysis is used for project scheduling.

options.label: D
options.text: Cost-Benefit Analysis evaluates staff performance, whereas Cost-Effective Analysis evaluates patient outcomes.

questions.correct_answer: B. Cost-benefit analysis compares monetary costs and benefits, whereas Cost-Effectiveness Analysis compares the costs to achieve a specific non-monetary outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding Work Sampling as a health management technique?

options.label: A
options.text: Work Sampling involves systematic observation and recording of activities at random intervals to estimate the proportion of time spent on different tasks.

options.label: B
options.text: Work Sampling is used for the evaluation of Doctors, Nurses, and Pharmacists.

options.label: C
options.text: Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.

options.label: D
options.text: Work Sampling is a quantitative type of health management technique.

questions.correct_answer: C. Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.
